author: Staff Reporter
text:
Consul General Philip Min said the number of students travelling from India to the U.S. had risen by 30 per cent last year —Photo : S.R. Raghunathan

The number of students travelling from India to study in the United States increased by 30 per cent in the last year, Philip Min, U.S. Consul General in Chennai, said on Wednesday.

Mr. Min said India was second only to China in terms of the number of overseas students studying in the United States. “132,000 students came to our country last year. This is the highest since we started keeping track a few years ago,” he added. Mr. Min was speaking to the media during a presentation by EducationUSA, a global network supported by the U.S Department of State’s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs.

The network has seen thousands of Indian students approaching the centre for advice, he said. “Last year 1,20,000 students contacted the centre while considering travelling to the United States for education. I get a lot of questions on why youth should choose the United States for education. To that, I say there is a diversity of options, be it vocational schools or culinary institutes,” he added.

When asked about the Indian students who were turned back from entering the country, he clarified they were not deported but only denied entry for some reason. “But this issue, in my opinion, will not affect the number of students coming to the country to study,” he said.
title: ‘U.S offers a diversity of options in education’
